<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023

2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 720, 96]]<|/det|>
By considering \((r + 1)^2 - r^2\), use the method of differences to prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 100, 609, 134]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r = \textstyle {\frac{1}{2}}n(n + 1). \quad (4)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 621, 91]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for all positive integers \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 92, 715, 128]]<|/det|>
\[1 + 2x + 3x^{2} + \ldots +nx^{n - 1} = \frac{1 - (n + 1)x^{n} + nx^{n + 1}}{(1 - x)^{2}}. \quad [6]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 771, 96]]<|/det|>
The quartic equation \(x^{4} + bx^{3} + cx^{2} + dx - 2 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma , \delta\) . It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 103, 856, 127]]<|/det|>
\[\alpha +\beta +\gamma +\delta = 3,\qquad \alpha^{2} + \beta^{2} + \gamma^{2} + \delta^{2} = 5,\qquad \alpha^{-1} + \beta^{-1} + \gamma^{-1} + \delta^{-1} = 6.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 136, 144, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 136, 384, 156]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(b, c\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 186, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 631, 761, 650]]<|/det|>
Given also that \(\alpha^{3} + \beta^{3} + \gamma^{3} + \delta^{3} = -27\), find the value of \(\alpha^{4} + \beta^{4} + \gamma^{4} + \delta^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 390, 92]]<|/det|>
The lines \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) have equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 102, 821, 123]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{r} = -2\mathbf{i} - 3\mathbf{j} - 5\mathbf{k} + \lambda (-4\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j} + 5\mathbf{k})\qquad \mathrm{and}\qquad \mathbf{r} = 2\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j} + 3\mathbf{k} + \mu (2\mathbf{i} - 3\mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 220, 153]]<|/det|>
respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 144, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 507, 184]]<|/det|>
Find the shortest distance between \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 680, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi\) contains \(l_{1}\) and the point with position vector \(-\mathbf{i} - 3\mathbf{j} - 4\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 719, 122]]<|/det|>
Find an equation of \(\varPi\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 571, 92]]<|/det|>
Let \(k\) be a constant. The matrices \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\) are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 98, 761, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k & 3 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}, \qquad \mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \qquad \text{and} \qquad \mathbf{C} = \begin{pmatrix} -2 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 351, 183]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathbf{A}\) is singular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 144, 210]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 186, 391, 216]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathbf{CAB} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -7 \\ -9 & 3 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 186, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 567, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x - y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{CAB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 915, 101]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 915, 135]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 154, 915, 170]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 190, 915, 205]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 787, 322]]<|/det|>
The matrices \(\mathbf{D}\), \(\mathbf{E}\) and \(\mathbf{F}\) represent geometrical transformations in the \(x - y\) plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 335, 560, 352]]<|/det|>
* \(\mathbf{D}\) represents an enlargement, centre the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 350, 531, 367]]<|/det|>
* \(\mathbf{E}\) represents a stretch parallel to the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 365, 529, 383]]<|/det|>
* \(\mathbf{F}\) represents a reflection in the line \(y = x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 517, 415]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{CAB} = \mathbf{D} - 9\mathbf{EF}\), find \(\mathbf{D}\), \(\mathbf{E}\) and \(\mathbf{F}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 504, 91]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve with Cartesian equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 101, 566, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\left(x - \frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} + y^{2} = \frac{1}{4}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 144, 384, 163]]<|/det|>
has polar equation \(r = \cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 331, 460, 351]]<|/det|>
The curves \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\) have polar equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 361, 611, 380]]<|/det|>
\[r = \cos \theta \quad \mathrm{and} \quad r = \sin 2\theta\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 888, 413]]<|/det|>
respectively, where \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\). The curves \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\) intersect at the pole and at another point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 144, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 424, 410, 443]]<|/det|>
Find the polar coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 424, 920, 443]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 144, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 580, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
In a single diagram sketch \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\), clearly identifying each curve, and mark the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 579, 922, 598]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 668, 91]]<|/det|>
The region \(R\) is enclosed by \(C_{1}\) and \(C_{2}\) and includes the line \(OP\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 103, 421, 121]]<|/det|>
Find, in exact form, the area of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 591, 103]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \frac{x^{2} + 2}{x^{2} - x - 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 489, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 485, 186, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 485, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on \(C\), giving your answers correct to 1 decimal place.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 501, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 682, 89]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 520, 144, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 515, 479, 541]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \frac{1}{\mathrm{f}(x)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
